arch:property.oc:show_val: This locus is the pit containing two burials. Individual one (I1) was interred in an extended position, head west and feet east, with the legs bent at the knees and sitting up and to the north. Individual one was distrubed when Individual two (I2) was interred. I1"s right arm and head were displaced, but the rest of the body was found properly articulated. The disturbed parts of I1 were placed over it"s neck and I2 was laid over I1"s head in a bundle. That is, I2 seems to have been interred secondarily in a pile of disarticulated bones. It is difficult to say which cranium belongs to I1 and I2. They were found back to back, facing opposite directions, both slighly off center of their proper position at the top of I1"s neck. My sense tells me that I1"s head is the one facing SE and I2"s head faces NE. I assume this because what I believe to be I1"s left arm was found under I1"s displaced skull. It seems likely that the displaced bones, head and left arm, were set there and then I2"s body added. Also noteworthy is the absence of all but a single piece of a mandible. Fully 1.5 mandibles are missing fromthis burial. They either went missing when the southern baulk of F1 was cut and eroded in previous seasons. Or, more likely, I2"s mandible was not interred at all because it was a secondary burial, and I1"s mandible was disturbed when digging a pit for I2. Thus only part of I1"s mandible made it back into the pit. Finally, I1"s skull had the first cervical vertebra stuck to the base of the crania by dirt. This finding is more in keeping with the primary, articulated condition of I1, versus I2, which feels secondary and if so is not likely to have its vertebra preserved. The metal pin was found near the pelvis of I1 but a a higher level, suggesting that it is disturbed from its original position but I still feel that it belongs to I1 because it was not associated with the bones of I2.
10 YR 5/2 greyish brown mottled with 7.5YR 4/6 strong brown (brick debris)
pebbles and loam. loose to compact.

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Kenan Tepe: Area F / Trench 22 / Locus 6 (Locus)
